<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module4_mcq_q64')" data-correct-answer="B">
  <strong style="display: block;">A conglomerate applies its corporate WACC (computed from firm-wide averages) to evaluate all new projects across divisions. What is the most compelling theoretical objection to this practice?</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q64" value="A"> A. It may underestimate the NPV of large projects relative to small ones.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q64" value="B"> B. It ignores project-specific risk, leading to potential acceptance of overly risky projects and rejection of safer ones.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q64" value="C"> C. The WACC already reflects diversification across divisions, so it cannot be misapplied.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q64" value="D"> D. It violates Modigliani–Miller’s irrelevance proposition.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q64" value="E"> E. Corporate WACC is always higher than project-specific discount rates.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module4_mcq_q64" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. Using a single WACC disregards heterogeneity of project risk. This biases capital budgeting: risky projects appear too attractive, and safe projects appear unattractive.
